comments.commentBody:
agree with the above from ann arbor..

the fourth year is key in broadening one's medical knowledge as we well developing more mature clinical skills prior to the actual practice of medicine. we do not treat patients with test scores. if a student feels his fourth year is a waste, then that is a reflection of his/her insight and self starting characteristics.

shortening time, if it must occur, should come from undergraduate education, not medical school..

go blue!!

a 4 year college and 4 year medical school graduate.

As a proud Ann Arbor grad of a 6-year combined pre-med / med program 25 years ago, I concur with commenters who would reduce time from the undergrad portion of training, but not the medical school part. I missed out on some college life, but not much. If I had less medical training, I'd be a less knowledgeable doctor, plain and simple.

I disagree with those who feel that "fat' should be cut from the 4th year of medical school. This is not a time for loafing, but for exploration and consolidation. Without my 4th year training, I would essentially only know my own specialty. And every doctor knows that non-specialty training is useful and important, for oneself, for one's extended family, and for one's patients.

Someday Public Option Universal Healthcare will likely become reality. That will probably drive down physician salaries. To compensate, medical school tuition will become more heavily subsidized, reducing graduates' debt loads.

Free markets work by entrepreneurs borrowing money to create businesses. Governments must borrow money to provide safe environments with adequate infrastructure.

Wake up! We're no longer in the nineteenth century. Finance must advance along with technology in the modern world!

Alan Greenspan.

Ironic that, Greenspan, the man famous for remarking about market behavior that it owed to "irrational exuberance."

The clique of November losers, all of whom would have cared nothing for their predictions about rate behavior had they defeated Barack Obama, aren't restrain now by good old fashioned "irrational fear of the monster in the closet."

That would be humorous if they didn't wield so much power.

Millions of jobs, the economies of nations, are on the line and because they aren't driving the White House and giving orders to Congressional regulation of the markets, to Treasury, to the SEC, and directing Federal investigations of market practices, they cower in their beds like the psychological child-aged bullies they haven't matured beyond, afraid of what they imagine and what others control.

All hail the monster in the closet!

Republican economic claims, starting with Reagan's supply-side fantasy, have been disproving themselves since 1986 when Reagan's own budget dirtector (David Stockman) wrote a book on the topic.  But Dr. Krugman is being too kind when he refers to this zombie economic  belief system as a cult. The term "cult" implies that its adherents actually believe their own claims- they no longer do. These are not "true believers", they are more like swindlers- charlatans engaged in a political charade designed to dupe the ignorant by people who know better. Remember Romney's cynical comments before his $50.000 a plate funders?  It is a marketing strategy- not a serious economic theory.

Money don't spoil and corrupt politicians. Ignorant and indifferent voters do.

Getting money out of politics is not possible because it is protected by the First Amendment. NRA has its right to fund and promote its agenda, so is Michael Bloomberg.

The viable alternative is to make the donor-receiver information transparent. Media or a private foundation will have to step up on this front.

"The paralysis in getting things done, where banking is concerned, comes from both sides of the aisle…"

No. You are wrong to make both sides equally culpable. Life as it is lived does not fall into neat boxes.
i agree with your hope. I only wish that I could believe in the possibility.

"It is imperative that policy makers speed up the rules to help correct critical vulnerabilities in the financial system."

It is imperative that US campaign finance reform, real reform, happen first. Without freeing our representatives in both houses of Congress, nothing of any real substance will happen. All too many are beholden to their corporate donors and connected to former colleagues on the House and senate floors.

The paralysis in getting things done, where banking is concerned, comes from both sides of the aisle and was clearly and amply illustrated in the campaign for the Massachusetts senate seat, with the banks resolutely attempting to defeat Elizabeth Warren's candidacy. Support for her candidacy from outside Massachusetts was instrumental in her win.

Reforming our banking system and making agreements with other nations, real ones, will take some work. We know what needs to be done. We need the right environment in place.

Getting rid of money in politics is the hardest thing this nation has in front of it. Once done, everything else will fall into pieces.

One approach to stemming this relentless progression of mass murder by guns could be to re-classify these events not simply as "crimes" or "homicides", but rather, as acts of DOMESTIC TERRORISM, which is precisely what they are.  We should use the capabilities developed since 9/11 and apply these tools and lessons to this problem to identify, locate and preempt the plans other lonely madmen who would kill as many innocents as possible to satisfy their own twisted demons, i.e. terrorists.

I worked as a librarian at Adelphi University when Colin Ferguson was a student there. He used to ask to use the Reference Desk phone and he would always be arguing loudly with the Bursar or Registrar offices. He liked me be because when he asked me to, I spoke to people who spoke too loudly in study groups (they always said "We were here first.He came and sat nearby, even though the study room was empty.") And then he complained to me. People in power shirk responsibility. I guess that's nothing new. University politics are the most vicious because the stakes are so small. And then it's left to the part - time reference libn to handle it on a Sunday afternoon or a weeknight near 10 pm. Meanwhile,I wrote him up and flagged him as a problem and it went nowhere. "whaa? who?. "

The NRA would love that. A weak Federal Gun law to wipe out all the local restrictions in place now. Why should New Mexico, or Montana be subjected to NYC like restrictions; or New York or Chicago weak regulations?

I add that my daughter committed suicide at age 19 so I witnessed what she as a human being went through and see it comparable to what this young man went through. The anger people feel for not being seen as another human being is really problem that not many understand. My daughter was bullied seven years before she took her own life. Even with professional help which I think very little of, it took my own change of mindset to learn to earn her trust and respect to honestly connect with her. In my good-bye letter she even wrote that I was the only one who kept her hanging on for as long as she did.

Another thing that I take to my grave is hearing her mother cry with her death. I wish all males could go through something like that so they would have some understanding how our ignorance about relationships in our country are really sick. This young man's father remarried and that's when a real shift took place in him. His mother had no support in attempting to cover his father's role in his life. I mean the greatest gift a father can give to his children is to love their mother.

Our society has lost plain old common sense and turned life from being simple to being complicated. Try to find just the basics of self-esteem, self-love and self confidence in those that make up our society. We turned our schools into treating humans like they're robots where we program their minds for jobs but not relating to one another. Maybe enough of these suicides might wake us up sometime.
Joan-You have described the situation very well.

So the proposition is to cut medical school length as we have already reduced resident work hours? This will indeed churn out more well rested doctors, but those of us who are actually currently practicing fear for the future of medicine. This new breed of doctor does not have the proper training and will provide substandard care compared to the physicians of old. It appears this trend will worse into the future as Americans get older, fatter, and sicker and as medicine gets more complex.

HC has absolutely no sense. I am so sick of people complaining that physicians are overpaid. Insurance companies actively try to deny care to patients yet the physicians who actively try to PROVIDE care are vilified. No one seems to mind that an insurance company's CEO makes 10 million/ year or that a hospital CEO makes 10 million/year but the internist who makes 100K/year is overpaid? Get a clue.
So much easier to address straw man arguments than the real ones, isn't it.

"When the economy is growing and the outlook is positive, the deficits and debt are not a problem."

That produces a bubble. That is what Republicans did. That is exactly how THEY ruined our economy. You can't now blame Dr. Krugman for what the Republicans did. They never followed his advice.

Unfortunately, neither has Obama.
Wayne, the goal of economic policy is to predict what will happen in the relatively near term.  In the long term, EVERYTHING will happen, so it doesn't need to be predicted.

When the economy is growing and the outlook is positive, the deficits and debt are not a problem. We can afford it. Keep spending.

When the economy is weak and the outlook is bleak, we cannot afford to reduce the deficits and debt due to the adverse impact on the economy. Keep spending.

The consequence of this thing will be similar to global warming ....... you may not notice it now but there will be a price to pay in the form of a slow degradation in the standard of living and quality of life.

The fact that sky has not yet fallen is not a sound argument against the existence of a serious problem.

My brother did this for our mother.  Unfortunately, it was so I could take care of her during the last year of her terminal illness.  People with grandparents who are healthy and nearby are lucky, and if it takes money to produce this, more power to the people who spend it.

One, I presume you're inferring that the GOP is the obstructionist party.  Two, if so, you are correct.  Three, the economic earthquake is precisely what happened when the Fed curtailed "easy money" circa 1932 (or was it 1934/36; I've recently read an article but cannot find it right now).  Four, thus the incipient recovery that began shortly after FDR's election was derailed by arguments little different from today's.  Five, America's recovery was artificially "estopped" until the attack on Pearl Harbor changed things.  Six, must we have yet another war to create economic growth again?

Bad auto-correct! My last sentence should read:

Getting rid of money in politics is the hardest thing this nation has in front of it. Once done, everything else will fall into place.

The people being discussed here do not operate on the basis of facts, their record of accomplishment, or their success at prediction; they operate on the basis of being authority figures. Error is not in the job description. They can not admit to error without losing authority. And authority is all they have when it comes down to it.

What we need is a massive "The Emperor has no clothes" moment. Unfortunately, the kind of economic disaster too big for them to ignore, explain away, or fade from memory is liable to be terribly hard on the rest of us.

Again.

And there's no guarantee they won't climb out of the rubble right back into positions of authority again.

Thank you Dr. Krugman for continuing to try to warn us about what's going on. With enough repetition and continued failure on the part of the Very Serious People, the message may yet get through.
You're one of the true believers, aren't you? The problem is lack of demand. The rich won't buy enough to spur demand but they have the great bulk of the wealth. That's the root of the problem.

If you claim that the questions cannot be answered affirmatively with certainty, then why ask them? In fact, you are claiming to already have the answers to the questions, but this is what you have to prove. You are engaging in a species of logical fallacy known as the Vicious Circle.  You are also employing the fallacy of Weak Analogy (again, you need to prove that the debt is in itself as dangerous as major climate change and that they have any clear relationship with each other)  and throwing in a heap of information that doesn't support your point, such as it is. Before accusing Mr. Krugman of committing logical fallacies (which he hasn't), you should take a course in logic so that you understand what a logical fallacy is.

I think that Krugman has answered you quite clearly. You pay down the debt in times of prosperity, not in times of hardship. We were doing that in the Clinton years. Stopped in the Bush years, and then the crash. After the economy recovers, then we pay down the debt. Furthermore, he would say spend less on the military. That is weaponized stimulus and it isn't very effective over the long run. If you read his columns, all these things are there and answer your critique quite clearly and effectively.

Questions for PK: 1) is there no level of debt that is unsustainable? 2) is it impossible that interest rates rise significantly before we have a plan for our debt? 3) is it guaranteed that we will return to robust economic growth in the next 10-20 years?

If these questions cannot be answered affirmatively with certainty, and they cannot, then we should get serious about a plan to control our debt, or we are risking a currency crisis, the loss of the dollar as reserve currency and the downfall of our country and way of life. As has been said, we cannot spend our way to prosperity, or use more debt to get ourselves out of debt.

Like other empires in history, we are not immune to failure, and it can happen swiftly. No red light will flash when we cross the event horizon. I am sure PK and his followers are advocates of the precautionary principle for prevention of global warming; how can it be rationalized that our debt issue is not analogous, while it is potentially more under our control. In the meantime, instead of facing reality, the Fed manipulates interest rates, distorts our economy and punishes the prudent, while our Presidents and Congress shows no responsibility or leadership. PK's lack of epistemological modesty and caution and his promulgation of logical fallacies are dangerous, fail the Lucas critique and would have Keynes rolling in his grave.
The winners may wtire history in South Korea, but we here know better.

I would put the ball in Kim's court.  There is no reason to believe that overtures are viewed by the North as anything but an opportunity to get more than they give. And the more they get, the more leverage they will have to get more, in a never ending nightmare for the South.  Of course, we may be at that point already, where South Korea pays ever more tribute to the North in return for not being demolished.
Mr A. R. Hunt wrote: "It didn’t used to be that way". He needs to consult his HS English grammar text book!

Louis Bouillot Cremant Rose and his Blanc de Noir for Xmas. Love them both and will be serving proudly. The dry sparkling of thr Rose with the clean finish of berry is delightful and Maude's me want to share with everyone.

In teaching drawing to adults I see the same problem.  It is a basic human problem.  When people form a gestalt they cling to it even when it's obviously wrong. Getting people to challenge their assumptions is one of the most difficult things I know, and with drawing there is no financial investment. It's only a matter of a little time and energy.  Once you get research grants involved, or manufacturing interests as in the case of the military and the gun industry you have the solid gold version of the same dilemma.

Faith is what matters to Republicans. They are unconcerned with the mathematics and logic of economics or for that matter science in general.
That is why no amount of arguing seems to matter.
Having the better argument is not the primary matter. What matters is creating a cult like following that will go wherever you want it to go, regardless of reason.
That explains the NRA and it explains why no amount of calculus, no matter how correct, will convince those who have chosen a different path, even if that path takes them over a cliff.
Global warming is material, economy is virtual, like the value of gold; a belief. This is why mathematics and basic science are ill equiped to predict economic tendencies.

Professor Krugman, you speak as if these deficit scolds are completely clueless about the implications of their arguments, but I don't think they all are.

They are looking at the longer term, which is: how can we get tax rates low and keep them low, disinvest as much as possible from the public goods and commons, and privatize everything so that our friends and other elites gain most of the benefits, and how can we globalize these actions so that they constitute a system that will sustain elites all over the world?

They have Wall Street, most central banks, the IMF and World Bank, the establishment media in most countries, and other national and international systems working on their behalf, but non-elites still see through it. But they also know that if you repeat something enough, it starts to stick, so they're not going to quit. And since there are no consequences not just for being wrong but causing massive global destruction and disruption (cf. Bush administration), why should or would they?

Andrew:

What convenient memory.

Like the good Keynesian that he claims to be, Prof. Krugman owns up that deficits should be controlled more attentively when society regains prosperity. The problem, of course, is that when that happens, the argument shifts: now that society is prosperous, and all those dreadful people who earn ten cents more than they need to purchase gruel can even better afford being soaked for social transformation experiments, it's a matter of investment; and the things in which the 1% should invest for the benefit of the 99% are quite literally legion: a far more pervasive and generous social safety net, improved education with a more focused national rather than local flavor, a greening of our economy regardless of the short- and mid-term hits to employment and compensations, a broadening of government to better regulate industry and commerce that, after all, operate merely at the pleasure of the people. Quite a party.

Thus, exceptions need to be made even in prosperous times to social "needs" that trump arithmetic. So much for Keynesian balance. Indeed, these are precisely the "investments" Dr. Krugman advises whether we're prosperous and can afford them, or broke and can't. One must give him points for consistency.

Prof. Krugman is a stridently self-avowed liberal; and, while I'm occasionally willing to give him the benefit of the doubt, his economics often seem fashioned merely to support that agenda.
